results.brief_description: Ever wondered what a flea circus was really like? Well have a look at the Cardoso Flea Circus.

results.title: Psycho samba
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and audio
results.brief_description: ‘Suddenly a bolt of electricity sprang forth from the screen and hit me in the head, scorching my forehead with uncanny resemblance of a burn that looked like a human eye. I could hear a buzzing in my ears, my newly formed third eye then began to secrete a special metallic-tasting liquid, as I saw visions of atomic bomb mushroom clouds.’ - Ian Haig (Chicago Underground Film Fest)

results.title: Mind's eye
results.brief_description: An experimental animation made with over 1200 photographs. The film revels in situationist surreality and takes the viewer on a roller-coaster journey through a series of locations.

results.title: AstroTurf
results.creator_credit: Ian Haig, Rod Bishop, Australian Film Commission and Magnetic Monster Video
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: ‘AstroTurf’ is a 3-D animation that tours through periods of time that mark different technologies, from the prehistoric to beyond the 21st century. As the technology advances, human evolution is virtually at a standstill, always at odds with the technology that is demonstrated to be fallible. Ian Haig uses bold graphic style drawing on influences such as; 1950s television, sci-fi imagery, computer games, cartoons and comic books. ‘AstroTurf’ becomes a platform to celebrate computer imaging and the alternate aesthetics that the medium allows for.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ian Haig, Rod Bishop, Australian Film Commission and Magnetic Monster Video

results.title: Random cuts
results.brief_description: At first glance, ‘Random cuts’ is a violent, rapidly shifting assemblage of images of violence, flight and impact from manga cinema, samurai films and a brutal cock-fight. On closer inspection, the apparent randomness of the images is revealed to be constrained by a mathematical formula. 12 images, each 1.6 seconds in length add and divide, repeating 12 times, increasing by the duration of the accumulating time units. The forceful incisions of the images and cuts find a taut restraint within this order, each element unresolved amid the visual violence.

results.title: The Illustrated Auschwitz
results.creator_credit: Kathy Drayton, Lucia Salinas Briones, Jackie Farkas and AFTRS
results.brief_description: Jackie Farkas uses the extraordinary and harrowing oral testimony of an elderly Hungarian woman as the basis for a poetic and abstract investigation into how cinema can ‘illustrate’ such profoundly horrendous experiences. The use of found footage, elusive images of beauty and horror and sequences from ‘The Wizard of Oz’ to elucidate the narrator’s memories creates an extraordinary representation of the holocaust experience, of survival, of home and memory, and of how we can comprehend the incomprehensible.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kathy Drayton, Lucia Salinas Briones, Jackie Farkas and AFTRS

results.title: Blood
results.brief_description:
Travelling through Australia with his film camera, Ivan Sen has visited many Aboriginal communities, from urban to prison to distant-rural. Photographing people in their definitive environments, he has created an installation which is a subtle and deeply moving meditation on skin, landscape, gesture and the many nuances of Aboriginal identities.

The work contains imagery of people who have all shared the same blood. The blood of the Gamilaroi people of Northern NSW.

results.title: Night cries: a rural tragedy
results.brief_description: In Tracey Moffatt’s re-imaging of the pivotal Australian film “Jedda”, a middle-aged Aboriginal woman returns to her outback home to nurse her dying white mother. Filmed against lushly coloured sets that recall the technicolour glories of the past, and utilising a harsh discordant soundscape, “Night Cries” occupies the landscape of dreams and the classic mythic terrain of familial violence and betrayal. This short film does more than simply reconfigure and re-imagine past narratives. It inaugurated a clear and permament break with previous moving image representations of the “outback”: no longer the pretence that it is a place outside language and history.

constellations_other.name: Indigenous futurisms
constellations_other.description: An exploration of works that put First Peoples futurisms first.
